when that experiment the idea it was called Blazer initially and
the experiment evolved in a handful of ways the first iteration of Blazer was what we call Blazer server which
coincidentally enough is the same development experience but the way that
you get information from the server to the UI was using like a websocket client
or signalr client to send the diff of a Dom back and forth so kind of tricking you into thinking
that it's like running in the browser because there's no postbacks or there's no anything but it's still making calls
back out to the server and then there was an implementation of blazer for
webassembly called Blazer wasm and that uses the mono run time to
basically compile your c-sharp application into a into a particular format that
runs in the browser and there are some positives to that right like you can run this in very small environments right
like that like you don't need a server so you can run them in places that you would not expect them to be able to run
you have access to the full.net runtime so you have access to all the great things that we're used to as we build on

your particular systems but there are drawbacks right for instance bless you
for instance you can't have an experience that's offline

also latency there's also size of the project because you're loading the.net
runtime into your app right into the browser and there's server resources that do
come along that because you're going to eventually have to make some service calls but these are similar cons that you
